sen.j: 城柵（じょうさく）とは古代日本の律令制下、現代の新潟県北部及び東北地方を支配下に治めるために設置した防御施設を備えた官衙を指す歴史学用語。
sen.e: Josaku is a historical term for a government office with defending facilities that was located to govern the north part of present-day Niigata Prefecture and the Tohoku region under the ritsuryo system during the ancient Japan.

Josaku is a historical term for a government office with defending facilities that was located to govern the north part of present-day Niigata Prefecture and the Tohoku region under the ritsuryo system during the ancient Japan.

Josaku is a historical term for a government office with defending facilities that was located to govern the north part of present-day Niigata Prefecture and the Tohoku region under the ritsuryo system during the ancient Japan.

sen.j: 史料上では「○×城」、「○×柵」として記録されているところから、それらを城柵と総称する。
sen.e: Since it is referred to as 'XX jo' or 'XX saku' in historical documents, 'josaku' is used here as a generic term.
Since it is referred to as 'XX jo' or 'XX saku' in historical documents, 'josaku' is used here as a generic term.
Since it is referred to as 'XX jo' or 'XX saku' in historical documents, 'josaku' is used here as a generic term.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

sen.j: 当時は、どちらの字も「き」と読んでいたらしい。
sen.e: It is believed that both 'jo' and 'saku' were read as 'ki' in those times.
It is believed that both 'jo' and 'saku' were read as 'ki' in those times.
It is believed that both 'jo' and 'saku' were read as 'ki' in those times.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

sen.j: 前九年の役、後三年の役で安倍氏 (奥州)や出羽清原氏が軍事拠点として設置した柵は成り立ちや性格が異なるので、一般的にはここでいう城柵には含めない。
sen.e: The saku that were located as military footholds by the Abe clan of Oshu and the Dewa Kiyohara clan during Zen Kunen no Eki (the Early Nine Years' War) and Gosannen no Eki (the Later Three Years' War) were different in nature from 'josaku,' so they are generally not included in the 'josaku' discussed here.

The saku that were located as military footholds by the Abe clan of Oshu and the Dewa Kiyohara clan during Zen Kunen no Eki (the Early Nine Years' War) and Gosannen no Eki (the Later Three Years' War) were different in nature from 'josaku,' so they are generally not included in the 'josaku' discussed here.

The saku that were located as military footholds by the Abe clan of Oshu and the Dewa Kiyohara clan during Zen Kunen no Eki (the Early Nine Years' War) and Gosannen no Eki (the Later Three Years' War) were different in nature from 'josaku,' so they are generally not included in the 'josaku' discussed here.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

tit.e: Areas along Josaku in the Japan Sea
Areas along Josaku in the Japan Sea
Areas along Josaku in the Japan Sea

sen.j: 大化3年（647年）、渟足柵が現在の新潟市沼垂付近に設置されたのが記録に残る初見である。
sen.e: The Nutari no Ki located about present-day Nutari, Niigata City in 647 is the first josaku ever recorded.
The Nutari no Ki located about present-day Nutari, Niigata City in 647 is the first josaku ever recorded.
The Nutari no Ki located about present-day Nutari, Niigata City in 647 is the first josaku ever recorded.

sen.j: 翌、大化4年（648年）には磐舟柵が現在の村上市岩船付近に設置された。
sen.e: In 648, Iwafune no Ki was located around today's Iwafune, Murakami City.
In 648, Iwafune no Ki was located around today's Iwafune, Murakami City.
In 648, Iwafune no Ki was located around today's Iwafune, Murakami City.

sen.j: また、斉明天皇4年（658年）には都岐沙羅柵という名が『日本書紀』に記されているが、いつどこに設置されたのかは全く不明である。
sen.e: A josaku named Tsukisara no Ki is also mentioned in "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan), but it is unclear when and where it was located.
A josaku named Tsukisara no Ki is also mentioned in "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan), but it is unclear when and where it was located.
A josaku named Tsukisara no Ki is also mentioned in "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan), but it is unclear when and where it was located.

sen.j: 更に『続日本紀』の和銅2年7月1日 (旧暦)（ユリウス暦709年8月10日）の条に出羽柵に武器を運搬したとの記載があることから、その時点には出羽柵が存在したことがわかる。
sen.e: Additionally, since an article dated August 10, 709 of "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) records that weapons were transported to Dewa no Ki, it is suggested that Dewa no Ki had existed by then.

Additionally, since an article dated August 14, 709 of "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) records that weapons were transported to Dewa no Ki, it is suggested that Dewa no Ki had existed by then.
sen.cmt: 年月日をグレゴリオ暦に訂正しました。
sen.e: Additionally, since an article dated August 14, 709 of "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) records that weapons were transported to Dewa no Ki, it is suggested that Dewa no Ki had existed by then.

sen.j: 出羽柵は出羽郡（現庄内地方）に設置されたと思われるが、詳しい位置については不明である。
sen.e: Although Dewa no Ki is considered to be located in Ideha gun, or the present-day Shonai region, its detailed location is unknown.
Although Dewa no Ki is considered to be located in Ideha gun, or the present-day Shonai region, its detailed location is unknown.
Although Dewa no Ki is considered to be located in Ideha gun, or the present-day Shonai region, its detailed location is unknown.

sen.j: また、和銅元年（708年）には越後国に出羽郡が設けられていることから、この前後の設置であろうと推測されている。
sen.e: In addition, the fact that Ideha (another name for Dewa) gun was established in 708 suggests that it was located around this time period.
In addition, the fact that Ideha (another name for Dewa) gun was established in 708 suggests that it was located around this time period.
In addition, the fact that Ideha (another name for Dewa) gun was established in 708 suggests that it was located around this time period.

sen.j: 和銅5年（712年）、出羽郡は出羽国に昇格し、出羽柵が国府とされた。
sen.e: In 712, Ideha gun was promoted to Dewa Province, with Dewa no Ki being its provincial capital.
In 712, Ideha gun was promoted to Dewa Province, with Dewa no Ki being its provincial capital.
In 712, Ideha gun was promoted to Dewa Province, with Dewa no Ki being its provincial capital.

sen.j: その後、出羽柵は天平5年12月26日 (旧暦)（ユリウス暦734年2月4日）に現在の秋田市に移設され、秋田城と改名されたと見られる。
sen.e: Subsequently, it is considered that Dewa no Ki was relocated to present-day Akita City on February 4, 734, and was renamed Akita-jo Castle.
Subsequently, it is considered that Dewa no Ki was relocated to present-day Akita City on February 8, 734, and was renamed Akita-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 年月日をグレゴリオ暦に訂正しました。
sen.e: Subsequently, it is considered that Dewa no Ki was relocated to present-day Akita City on February 8, 734, and was renamed Akita-jo Castle.

sen.j: しかし、蝦夷の居住地域の真ん中に設置されたことから、度々蝦夷との抗争により攻撃を受けた。
sen.e: However, with its location being in the middle of the northerners' residential area, it was subject to frequent attacks in conflicts with them.
However, with its location being in the middle of the northerners' residential area, it was subject to frequent attacks in conflicts with them.
However, with its location being in the middle of the northerners' residential area, it was subject to frequent attacks in conflicts with them.

sen.j: このため、延暦23年（804年）に国府を「河辺府」に移設したとされる。
sen.e: Therefore, its provincial capital is believed to have been relocated to 'Kawabe no fu' in 804.
Therefore, its provincial capital is believed to have been relocated to 'Kawabe no fu' in 804.
Therefore, its provincial capital is believed to have been relocated to 'Kawabe no fu' in 804.

sen.j: 但し、秋田城は放棄されず、軍事機能を強化して国司が駐在して指揮した。
sen.e: But Akita-jo Castle was not abandoned; with its military functions reinforced, a provincial governor resided and took the initiative.
But Akita-jo Castle was not abandoned; with its military functions being reinforced, a provincial governor resided and took the initiative.
sen.cmt: functions の後に、being を付け足しました。
sen.e: But Akita-jo Castle was not abandoned; with its military functions being reinforced, a provincial governor resided and took the initiative.

sen.j: このことから後に出羽介は秋田城介と呼ばれるようになる。
sen.e: For this reason, Dewa no suke (assistant governor of Dewa Province) came to be known as Akita-jo no suke.
For this reason, Dewa no suke (assistant governor of Dewa Province) came to be referred to as Akita-jo no suke.
sen.cmt: known を referred to as に変更しました。
sen.e: For this reason, Dewa no suke (assistant governor of Dewa Province) came to be referred to as Akita-jo no suke.

sen.j: また、国府の移設場所には様々な説があるが、最終的には現代の酒田市にある城輪柵に移設されたと見られている。
sen.e: Although there are various theories as to where its provincial capital was located, it has been concluded that it was located in Kinowa no Ki in today's Sakata City.
Although there are various theories as to where its provincial capital was located, it has been concluded that it was located in Kinowa no Ki in today's Sakata City.
Although there are various theories as to where its provincial capital was located, it has been concluded that it was located in Kinowa no Ki in today's Sakata City.

sen.j: また、天平宝字3年（759年）には雄勝郡に雄勝城が設置されている。
sen.e: 759 saw the function of Okachino Ki Castle in Ogachi gun.
759 saw the function of Okachino Ki Castle in Ogachi gun.
759 saw the function of Okachino Ki Castle in Ogachi gun.

sen.j: 雄勝城の詳細な位置は不明で、払田柵跡をそれに比定する意見もあるが、払田柵跡は記録に現れていない城柵であるという意見が有力である。
sen.e: The castle's detailed location is unknown, with some identifying it as the remains of Hotta no Ki, but it is widely believed that Hotta no Ki was never recorded in documents.
The castle's detailed location is unknown, with some identifying it as the remains of Hotta no Ki, but it is widely believed that Hotta no Ki was never recorded in documents.
The castle's detailed location is unknown, with some identifying it as the remains of Hotta no Ki, but it is widely believed that Hotta no Ki was never recorded in documents.

tit.e: Areas along Josaku in the Pacific
Areas along Josaku in the Pacific
Areas along Josaku in the Pacific

sen.j: 神亀元年（724年）大野東人によって多賀城が設置された。
sen.e: Taga-jo Castle was founded by ONO no Azumahito in 724.
Taga-jo Castle was founded by ONO no Azumahito in 724.
Taga-jo Castle was founded by ONO no Azumahito in 724.

sen.j: それ以前の陸奥国国府は現代の仙台市長町にある郡山遺跡であると見られている。
sen.e: Prior to this, the capital of Mutsu Province is considered to have been Koriyama Ruins in present-day Nagamachi, Sendai City.
Prior to this, the capital of Mutsu Province is considered to have been Koriyama Ruins in present-day Nagamachi, Sendai City.
Prior to this, the capital of Mutsu Province is considered to have been Koriyama Ruins in present-day Nagamachi, Sendai City.

sen.j: 『続日本紀』の天平9年（737年）の記事には多賀柵、玉造柵、色麻柵、新田柵、牡鹿柵の名が見られ、当時多賀城が多賀柵と呼ばれていたこと、ほぼ同時に現宮城県内に4つの城柵が設けられたことがわかっている。
sen.e: The names of Taga no Ki, Tamatsukuri no Ki, Shikama no Ki, Nitta no Ki and Ojika no Ki are seen in the entry dated 737 of "Shoku Nihongi," which records that four josaku were located at almost the same time in present-day Miyagi Prefecture.

The names of Taga no Ki, Tamatsukuri no Ki, Shikama no Ki, Nitta no Ki and Ojika no Ki are seen in the article dated 737 of "Shoku Nihongi," which records that four josaku were located at almost the same time in present-day Miyagi Prefecture.
sen.cmt: entry を article に訂正しました。
sen.e: The names of Taga no Ki, Tamatsukuri no Ki, Shikama no Ki, Nitta no Ki and Ojika no Ki are seen in the article dated 737 of "Shoku Nihongi," which records that four josaku were located at almost the same time in present-day Miyagi Prefecture.

sen.j: 8世紀後半になると桃生城、伊治城、覚べつ城（かくべつじょう）などが設けられる。
sen.e: The late 8th century saw the foundation of Mono-jo Castle, Iji-jo Castle and Kakubetsu-jo Castle.
The late 8th century saw the foundation of Mono-jo Castle, Iji-jo Castle and Kakubetsu-jo Castle.
The late 8th century saw the foundation of Mono-jo Castle, Iji-jo Castle and Kakubetsu-jo Castle.

sen.j: 9世紀にはいると現在の岩手県地域にも城柵が作られはじめ、延暦21年（802年）に坂上田村麻呂により胆沢城が設置され、鎮守府が多賀城から移された。
sen.e: In the 9th century, josaku were also located in the present-day Iwate region, as Isawa-jo Castle was founded by SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro in 802, to which Chinju-fu (Pacification and Defense Headquarters) were relocated from Taga-jo Castle.

In the 9th century, josaku were also started to be founded in the present-day Iwate region, as Isawa-jo Castle was founded by SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro in 802, to which Chinju-fu (Pacification and Defense Headquarters) were relocated from Taga-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: located を started to be founded に訂正しました。
sen.e: In the 9th century, josaku were also started to be founded in the present-day Iwate region, as Isawa-jo Castle was founded by SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro in 802, to which Chinju-fu (Pacification and Defense Headquarters) were relocated from Taga-jo Castle.

sen.j: 翌年には志波城が設置されたが、雫石川の氾濫により度々被害を受けたことから弘仁2年（811年）廃絶され、徳丹城に移設された。
sen.e: Shiwa-jo Castle was founded the following year, but being frequently damaged by flooding of Shizukuishi-gawa River, it was abolished in 811 and relocated to Tokutan no Ki, or Tokutan-jo Castle.
Shiwa-jo Castle was founded the following year, but being frequently damaged by flooding of Shizukuishi-gawa River, it was abolished in 811 and relocated to Tokutan no Ki, or Tokutan-jo Castle.
Shiwa-jo Castle was founded the following year, but being frequently damaged by flooding of Shizukuishi-gawa River, it was abolished in 811 and relocated to Tokutan no Ki, or Tokutan-jo Castle.

sen.j: 城柵は征夷の最前線基地であり、軍事的に蝦夷を屈服させた地域に軍事拠点として設けられた。
sen.e: Josaku acted as outposts designed to exterminate barbarians, and were located as military footholds in the areas that militarily brought northerners into submission.
Josaku acted as outposts designed to exterminate barbarians, and were located as military footholds in the areas that militarily brought northerners into submission.
Josaku acted as outposts designed to exterminate barbarians, and were located as military footholds in the areas that militarily brought northerners into submission.

sen.j: また、律令政府の配下に置かれたそれらの地域には北陸や関東から柵戸と呼ばれる多くの移民が送り込まれたが、それらの移民の拠点、支配するための官衙、配下に置いた俘囚（服属蝦夷）が朝貢したり、それに対する饗応をする役目も負っていた。
sen.e: Many immigrants called sakuto were sent from the Hokuriku and Kanto regions to these areas, which were under the ancient Japanese government, and which also served as a foothold for immigrants, an office for governance, and a site to hold banquets for subordinate barbarians who paid tributes to.

Many immigrants called sakuto were sent from the Hokuriku and Kanto regions to these areas, which were under the ancient Japanese government, and which also served as a foothold for immigrants, an office for governance, and a site to hold banquets for subordinate barbarians who paid tributes to.

Many immigrants called sakuto were sent from the Hokuriku and Kanto regions to these areas, which were under the ancient Japanese government, and which also served as a foothold for immigrants, an office for governance, and a site to hold banquets for subordinate barbarians who paid tributes to.

sen.j: それに対応するために各城柵には国司四等官・史生、鎮官などが城司に任命され、城柵を支配した。
sen.e: In response to this, kokushi shitokan (four officials of the provincial governor), shisho (people who peformed miscellaneous duties about documents) and chinkan (officials in charge of pacification and defense) were assigned to manage and govern each josaku.

In response to this, kokushi shitokan (four officials of the provincial governor), shisho (people who performed miscellaneous duties about documents) and chinkan (officials in charge of pacification and defense) were assigned to manage and govern each josaku.
sen.cmt: スペルミスのためperformed に訂正しました。
sen.e: In response to this, kokushi shitokan (four officials of the provincial governor), shisho (people who performed miscellaneous duties about documents) and chinkan (officials in charge of pacification and defense) were assigned to manage and govern each josaku.

sen.j: また、軍事力として坂東諸国から徴発された鎮兵が駐屯した。
sen.e: Soldiers were also dispatched as military force from the Bando countries to pacify and defend their area.
Soldiers were also dispatched as military force from the Bando countries to pacify and defend their area.
Soldiers were also dispatched as military force from the Bando countries to pacify and defend their area.

sen.j: 秋田城についてはこれらの機能に加えて渤海 (国)等の外国使節の饗応や北方諸民族との交易の場が設定されていたのではないかとする見解が、発掘結果等を踏まえて出されている。
sen.e: Given the excavated materials, it is viewed that Akita-jo Castle served as a site to entertain foreign envoys from countries such as Bokkai, or Bohai, and to trade with the northern peoples, in addition to the functions described above.

Given the excavated materials, it is viewed that Akita-jo Castle served as a site to entertain foreign envoys from countries such as Bokkai, or Bohai, and to trade with the northern peoples, in addition to the functions described above.

Given the excavated materials, it is viewed that Akita-jo Castle served as a site to entertain foreign envoys from countries such as Bokkai, or Bohai, and to trade with the northern peoples, in addition to the functions described above.

sen.j: 城司の権限は大きく、国司の権限を分掌し、設置された辺郡の郡司や辺郡内に居住する俘囚を支配し、鎮兵や俘囚により編成された俘軍の指揮権を持った。
sen.e: The castle lords had great authority and shared a part of the power of kokushi (provincial governor), as they ruled gunji (local magistrates) appointed to the gun (province) and barbarians residing within, and had a command of an army of soldiers and barbarians.

The castle lords had great authority and shared a part of the power of kokushi (provincial governor), as they ruled gunji (local magistrates) appointed to the gun (province) and barbarians residing within, and had a command of an army of soldiers and barbarians.

The castle lords had great authority and shared a part of the power of kokushi (provincial governor), as they ruled gunji (local magistrates) appointed to the gun (province) and barbarians residing within, and had a command of an army of soldiers and barbarians.

sen.j: 陸奥では中央に貢納する租庸調・庸の貢納が免除され、城柵の運営財源として使用された。
sen.e: Mutsu was exempt from paying Soyochoyo (Yo of Soyocho tax system; Labor or alternative goods) to the central government, and used financial resources for the management of josaku.
Mutsu was exempt from paying Soyochoyo (Yo of Soyocho tax system; Labor or alternative goods) to the central government, and those were used as financial resources for the management of josaku.
sen.cmt: コンマの後の文の主語がなかったため、those were used as に訂正しました。
sen.e: Mutsu was exempt from paying Soyochoyo (Yo of Soyocho tax system; Labor or alternative goods) to the central government, and those were used as financial resources for the management of josaku.

sen.j: 移民である柵戸は城柵の周辺に出身地域ごとに居住地を定められ、周辺を開墾したと見られている。
sen.e: Sakuko, or immigrants, were located, according to where they were from, around josaku in which they lived and cultivated the land.
Sakuko, or immigrants, were located, according to where they were from, around josaku in which they lived and cultivated the land.
Sakuko, or immigrants, were located, according to where they were from, around josaku in which they lived and cultivated the land.

sen.j: それを示すように、古代奥羽の郷名には板東と共通するものが見られる。
sen.e: As an illustration of this, Go-mei, the ancient Ou, and Bando, share the same history as to sakuto.
As an illustration of this, Go-mei, the ancient Ou, and Bando, share the same history as to sakuto.
As an illustration of this, Go-mei, the ancient Ou, and Bando, share the same history as to sakuto.

sen.j: しかし、柵戸の生活は厳しく、逃亡するものも多かった。
sen.e: However, sakuto lived harsh lives, and many of them took off.
However, sakuto lived harsh lives, and many of them got away.
sen.cmt: took off を got away に訂正しました。
sen.e: However, sakuto lived harsh lives, and many of them got away.

sen.j: 弘仁2年（811年）には陸奥出羽で百姓の墾田を収公するのを禁じる太政官符が出されたことが『類聚三代格』からわかる。
sen.e: "Ruiju sandai kaku" (Assorted regulations from Three Reigns) indicates that Daijokanpu (official documents of the Daijokan, the office of the supreme political leader) were issued in 811 to forbid confiscating peasants' newly cultivated land in Mutsu, Dewa provinces.

"Ruiju sandai kaku" (Assorted regulations from Three Reigns) indicates that Daijokanpu (official documents of the Daijokan, the office of the supreme political leader) were issued in 811 to forbid confiscating peasants' newly cultivated land in Mutsu, Dewa provinces.

"Ruiju sandai kaku" (Assorted regulations from Three Reigns) indicates that Daijokanpu (official documents of the Daijokan, the office of the supreme political leader) were issued in 811 to forbid confiscating peasants' newly cultivated land in Mutsu, Dewa provinces.

sen.j: その他にも度々柵戸の租税の一部を免除する布告を出し、慰留に努めている。
sen.e: Other official notices were issued on several occasions to exempt sakuto from a portion of their land tax, thereby comforting them.
Other official notices were issued on several occasions to exempt sakuto from a portion of their land tax, thereby comforting them.
Other official notices were issued on several occasions to exempt sakuto from a portion of their land tax, thereby comforting them.

sen.j: しかし、征夷政策の収束と共に10世紀頃から急速に城柵は廃れ、11世紀には史料上からも考古学的成果からも消滅する事が確認されている。
sen.e: But josaku went into a rapid decline in the 10th century along with the end of the government's policy against barbarians, and by the 11th century, it had disappeared from historical documents as well as archeological records.

But josaku went into a rapid decline since around the 10th century along with the end of the government's policy against barbarians, and by the 11th century, it had disappeared from historical documents as well as archeological records.
sen.cmt: １０世紀頃から のため since around the 10th century に訂正しました。
sen.e: But josaku went into a rapid decline since around the 10th century along with the end of the government's policy against barbarians, and by the 11th century, it had disappeared from historical documents as well as archeological records.

sen.j: 10世紀頃から俘囚と移民の混雑が進み、城柵の役割が終わったものと見られる。
sen.e: It is considered that the barbarians and immigrants had been increasingly intermingled since the 10th century, which put the roles of josaku to an end.
It is considered that the barbarians and immigrants had been increasingly intermingled since around the 10th century, which put the roles of josaku to an end.
sen.cmt: １０世紀頃から のため since around the 10th century に訂正しました。
sen.e: It is considered that the barbarians and immigrants had been increasingly intermingled since around the 10th century, which put the roles of josaku to an end.

sen.j: それと共に俘囚長と呼ばれる安倍氏 (奥州)、清原氏などが台頭する。
sen.e: Meanwhile, the Abe clan of Oshu and the Kiyohara clan, who were chiefs of barbarians, gained power.
Meanwhile, the Abe clan of Oshu and the Kiyohara clan, who were chiefs of barbarians, gained power.
Meanwhile, the Abe clan of Oshu and the Kiyohara clan, who were chiefs of barbarians, gained power.

sen.j: 考古学上の成果によると、一般的な城柵は小高い丘上に官衙が設置され、その周辺に鎮兵の住居を配置し、周囲を土塁、材木列塀などを巡らし、望楼を設けて防御を固めている。
sen.e: According to archaeological findings, a general josaku was consisted of an office mounted on an elevated hill, around which the residents of soldiers were located, with earthen walls and fences made of lumber around them, as wells as watchtowers to reinforce defenses.

According to archaeological findings, a general josaku was consisted of an office mounted on an elevated hill, around which the residents of soldiers were located, with earthen walls and fences made of lumber around them, as wells as watchtowers to reinforce defenses.

According to archaeological findings, a general josaku was consisted of an office mounted on an elevated hill, around which the residents of soldiers were located, with earthen walls and fences made of lumber around them, as wells as watchtowers to reinforce defenses.

sen.j: また、周辺には移民の開拓地が置かれ、有事には移民は城柵に避難したようである。
sen.e: In the surrounding area were outposts for immigrants, who retreated into the josaku in emergencies.
In the surrounding area were outposts for immigrants, who retreated into the josaku in emergencies.
In the surrounding area were outposts for immigrants, who retreated into the josaku in emergencies.

sen.j: 『養老令』によると「凡縁東辺北辺西辺諸郡人居、皆於城堡内安置。其営田之所、唯置庄舎。至農時堪営作者、出就庄田 謂、強壮者出就田舎、老少者留在堡内也。収歛訖勒還 謂、要勒而還於城堡也。」との記述があり、考古学の成果とほぼ一致する。
sen.e: For the most part, the descriptions in Yoro-ryo (Yoro Code) correspond to what has been found in archaeology.
sen.cmt: ※「 」内は訳が不明のため、意訳しました。
sen.e: For the most part, the descriptions "凡縁東辺北辺西辺諸郡人居、皆於城堡内安置。其営田之所、唯置庄舎。至農時堪営作者、出就庄田 謂、強壮者出就田舎、老少者留在堡内也。収歛訖勒還 謂、要勒而還於城堡也。"in Yoro-ryo (Yoro Code) correspond to what has been found in archaeology.
sen.cmt: コメントに意訳した、とありますが、漢字の部分の意訳はされていませんでしたので、意味不明な部分を訳文に付け加えました。意味解釈が困難なため訳出できず
sen.e: For the most part, the descriptions '凡縁東辺北辺西辺諸郡人居、皆於城堡内安置。其営田之所、唯置庄舎。至農時堪営作者、出就庄田 謂、強壮者出就田舎、老少者留在堡内也。収歛訖勒還 謂、要勒而還於城堡也。' in Yoro-ryo (Yoro Code) correspond to what has been found in archaeology.
sen.cmt: " " → ' '意味解釈が困難なため訳出できず
